Posts.Content: Hi Emily It looks like nobody was awake in the wee hours while you sat waiting to be seen! I'm sure you've been seen etc by now. Hope all is well and you've had some sleep  x
Posts.Title: Currently waiting in out of hours :(

Posts.Content: Hi Dreamthief I believe this was a duplicate post hence no responses at the time
Posts.Title: Sister with widespread metastases

Posts.Content: Well I now have a picture in my mind of you hoovering with your new earrings I saw the other day!
Posts.Title: Sister with widespread metastases

Posts.Content: Lily For the heartburn there is a drug called lansoprazole and it crushed my heartburn as soon as I took it. Might be worth asking for this at your onco appointment?
Posts.Title: June 2017 Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Kim In the week after I have my chemo, I feel very weak first thing in the morning until I have eaten. Also I am absolutely ravenous most of the time (steroids?) and have to have exactly what I want, yoghurt, jelly, sweets, chips .... the list goes on and on. I think if I was to fast, I'd feel really poorly. Also some medications have to taken with or after food.
Posts.Title: Fasting along side Chemo - Advice/Thoughts

Posts.Content: This is the bra I have! I got two black ones when I had my lumpectomy in December, and got the twin pack blue / navy a month ago when I started feeling better after my mastectomy.  Your post reminded me I need a white one and I've just placed my order for collection on Wednesday! I've always loved M&S underwear and never buy it from anywhere else. Bra-vo........
Posts.Title: I finally found a comfy bra:)

Posts.Content: Hi Lee There is a monthly chemotherapy thread which you can join, lots of information there including helpful links. I am having FEC-T also, am on to my second T on Thursday, I have written a little in my blog about how it has gone so far. You can see that by clicking on my username and then my blog posts. Good luck X
Posts.Title: Due to start chemo 24th May

Posts.Content: Hi This sounds like seroma? I'd speak with only the breast care nurse about this. If it does happen to be seroma, then compression in a good bra which separates the breasts can help. Hope you get some relief X
Posts.Title: odema or hematoma after masectomy?

Posts.Content: HimBoth Many thanks for that insight. I had dismissed the chemo as being the cause, as this pain gradually presented itself after starting the tamoxifen. I mentioned it to my nurse practitioner at my oncology review appointment and she said it was the tamoxifen. So you can see why I'd put it down to that. Not sure who to approach as practitioner has said either it'll go off or you'll get used to it (sorry what!) my BCN is quite frankly rubbish. Although I suppose she could discuss at the MDT meeting. Off to pick up my new glasses, this time varifocals, thanks chemo! Thanks guys
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen (for probably the millionth time)

Posts.Content: Hi All Haven't posted for a while as I seem to be getting back into the daily grind. All treatments complete and only check up appointments left to do (apart from permanent reconstruction but next breast clinic appt is December so not even thinking about that yet). My question is about tamoxifen and I apologise in advance as I know it's been talked to death. I've looked through historical posts and can't quite find an answer relevant to me. I've been taking tamoxifen for forty days. When I started I was still experiencing side effects from chemo so it has taken a while to narrow down what causes what. I now feel like I understand what the tamoxifen is doing. I was given wockhardt brand which, from memory, is a brand that some found the easiest to deal with.  I am suffering from painful hands and feet, escalating to wrists and ankles, sometimes reaching as far as the elbow and knee and occasionally one hip! The worst part for me is my thumb base, worse in my dominant hand, causing me to need help (or suffering pain if there's nobody around) when I try to do things like opening pop bottles, opening bags of crisps or similar, closing press studs, pulling up trousers, squeezing the toothpaste tube. I'm sure there's a hundred more things but you get the gist. I love to cross stitch and I'm afraid the pain is cramping my style in that area too. So, on to my question, has anyone been in the same boat, with this brand? (Or is it really the best one) And if so, was there anything that would ease the pain, or did you change brand successfully? I'm reluctant to change brand as one of my initial worries was that the tamoxifen would turn me into superbitch, but it has mellowed my mood massively and I don't get the irrational mood swings I was getting (my whole life) previously. Does anyone know if changing brand would have any effect in that area? Many thanks in advance as always.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen (for probably the millionth time)

Posts.Content: jb63 Hi Your pains could be due to after effects of chemo I have the same problems in my joints and fingers I can't open packets and do buttons etc and if I walk too far my ankles knees and hips play up getting out of bed at night is fun too.  I am on letrozole not tamoxifen my gp has prescribed pregablin and 30mg codiene for pains which help a bit.  Lucky me my finger nails decided to come off this weekend this rollercoaster is so much fun. I would check with your oncologist just to make sure what is causing these annoying aches and pains Maxinem  I was told they can last for months so I will just take things a day at a time and fingers crossed things will get better Hi JB thanks for your input - I wonder then if that proves (ish) the theory that it is PN causing the problem. I thought it was tamoxifen but you take a different product and have the same symptoms. I walk like my legs and feet are made of wood after I've sat or laid for a long time and have fallen over several times! I can't walk far and if I need a wee, I grind to a halt,  my energy is completely sapped until I've been! I also feel like there's little tiny spiders walking on the tops of my feet (great fun) oh dear - what a palaver!
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen (for probably the millionth time)

Posts.Content: Hi Andylou I had mastectomy In January.   If you are having a mastectomy, then all of your breast tissue will be removed. So, if there is any invasive cancer in there, it will only serve to confirm that a mastectomy was the right plan of action.  When my breast tissue was examined after the mastectomy, they found another, smaller invasive cancer in there which hadn't shown up on mammogram or ultrasound. I was so glad that the surgeon had decided on mastectomy as otherwise I feel I would have had a time bomb ticking inside me! Advice for your hospital stay and/or early days after surgery.... Small beanbag type cushion to help you get comfortable under your arm or between your arm and breast. Cloth small shopping bag to pop your drain into (if you're having one) which will help you get around hands free. Small blanket for laying on the couch watching box sets! Nice and cosy yet easy to pop away if you don't need it.  Get some post surgery bras. Marks And Spencer do a good range VAT free, there's a link in another thread. And ...... look after yourself! Best wishes for your op, we'll all be here waiting to see how it has gone Xxxxx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy on wednesday..any advice/tips?

Posts.Content: Hi Andylou The cotton bag is not essential, just makes it easier i.e. Hang the bag on your wrist while you open the toilet door or wash your hands etc. I've actually seen a lady have her drain in a gift bag like you'd buy from a card shop and she seemed to be managing ok It's just a shopping bag really. Next, primark, spring to mind. Mine were from next at around £3 or £4. There's a website called drain dollies I think but they charge a lot for them. Some hospitals have volunteers who make them and donate to the ward. Good luck x
Posts.Title: Mastectomy on wednesday..any advice/tips?

Posts.Content: Hi Diane, Please do take someone with you for the next appointment. I find I'm always asking my partner, 'what did they say about this or that?'. Jot down any questions you think you might want to ask, and even write down what they say if you feel it would help. Best wishes for your appointment, Come back and tell us how you got on. ((((Hugs))))
Posts.Title: possible breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi All My sister was diagnosed with breast cancer around four weeks before I was. She is 57 and I am 47. We seem to have virtually the same diagnosis, with slightly different treatments plans. She lives in Spain and I live in the U.K.
Posts.Title: how many people have had sisters who have also had BC

Posts.Content: Hi All 15 days past my first T. Three FEC already done. The soles and heels of my feet have been sore for several days. My toenails on my big toes have been sore as if I've had a combination of long toenails and tight shoes. Today my big toenails have turned purple at the cuticle and progressing up the nail. My question is, what to expect next. Do they just go black? Do they peel in layers? Or is it bye bye nail? If they go, do they go all in one go or do they disengage gradually and painfully? Oh the joys of cancer and the myriad of things I didn't even know existed! It's an education for sure!  Hope everyone is well this lovely May morning x
Posts.Title: Tips for a black toenail

Posts.Content: I've got my place booked on 18th May I'm not really one for make up and girly stuff ..... but then I decided that I wasn't really one for cancer chemo hair loss etc either!  I'll give it a go!
Posts.Title: Look Good Feel Better courses

Posts.Content: Hi Some people can get a hint of what's happening from the reaction at appointments. Some can't.  I would suggest making plans for each day to keep your mind busy. This will bring your appointment around sooner.  Make sure to take someone with you to the appointment who can help you recall what was said. Often people come away in a daze because the event is stressful for them. Best wishes to you for a busy weekend! Take care x
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer referral after my nans passed away from cancer the same...

Posts.Content: Hi Seapebbles, sorry you find yourself here but it really is a good place to be when you're feeling as you do, and waiting for appointments etc. There are many people who go to these clinics and do not receive a cancer diagnosis. Breast cancer is very treatable, so if you were unfortunate enough to receive a cancer diagnosis, you would very quickly be given a treatment plan. This would focus your mind and give you a stable platform from which to proceed. The first thing I told my daughter when I was diagnosed with cancer was,'but I'm absolutely NOT going to die so NEVER worry about that'. I actually believe that too. I have a friend who had the exact same symptoms as me but several months later. I was getting ready to console and advise. I didn't say this to her, but was really concerned for her. She came away from her mammogram and ultrasound with a diagnosis of a benign fibroadenoma. She went on holiday with her family to celebrate the relief! You just can't call it! Keep your chin up and keep reading and posting here.  X
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer referral after my nans passed away from cancer the same...

Posts.Content: Many thanks Dreamthief I'll give them a call Monday
Posts.Title: Tips for a black toenail

Posts.Content: Hi All, Reported my feet and toenails to chemo nurses, my first port of call, on Monday. As I had an appointment with onco on wednesday, they advised waiting until then and to let her know. I'd had many other issues after my first 'T' all of which caused my onco to reduce the dose for the next chemo which I had yesterday. She also gave me some additional steroids, slightly reduced dose for three additional days to push me past those rough moments.  One big toenail has stayed the same with just a small area of light bruising, the other is fully purple up to approx 70% of it's length. Fingernails are ridged across the way but no peel or flake as yet. The soles of my feet have started with what I call dry blisters, not sore, just peeling skin in a bubble begging to be picked off! I shall resist! And Kacang..... I always wear crocs around the house instead of slippers, although the slip on type like pool shoes with just the front band across. I bought a blue pair and a red pair for holidays several years ago. Very expensive at around £25 a pair but obviously last ages and perfect for popping on and off in harmony with my hot flushes and burning feet!  Happy weekend everyone, I am spending mine on the couch after knowingly overdoing it last time. Cross stitch, crafts and movies on the cards for me!
Posts.Title: Tips for a black toenail

Posts.Content: Amanda865 Hi Jo, thanks for your reassurance - so glad that your lymph nodes were clear, mine are so far but they will be checking this to be absolutely sure at the same time as my lumpectomy... keeping my fingers crossed X Do I wear my own dressing gown into theatre? Hi Amanda My local hospital has an access lounge who deal with all preparations for surgery, where you attend to get gowned up etc and then are escorted to theatre. Perhaps if your hospital has a unit similar you could call them to enquire? I didn't have a dressing gown, they gave me a hospital one to wear. They gave me paper pants, I presumed they would catheterise me, as they did when I'd had three Caesarian sections. But they had confidence in my bladder obviously and it doesn't seem to be the norm for breast surgery so that is a real plus point! It's a worrying time, but you will be well looked after no matter what.  Take care x
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Hattie So so pleased for you. Congratulations! Enjoy!
Posts.Title: 22yo terrified of core biopsy - and, well, everything

Posts.Content: Hi Rach I don't have an answer for you unfortunately but will be closely watching the responses. I am halfway through FEC-T having done the FEC part. I am suffering with my veins which are dark and painful. The skin on my hand is sunken in where the veins are. My arm hurts when I reach out for something or try to point at something.  When I spoke to my nurse consultant about this she said it can take months to come good. Best wishes X
Posts.Title: UNSIGHTLY ARM DUE TO VEINS.

Posts.Content: Hi Hattie You are in the right place for advice and reassurance on this, and are very welcome. If I was your age I would feel exactly the same. My daughter is 23 years old and she would be far more panicked than you right now. I have had several biopsies at the time of ultrasound over several years, and it really is fine. It can make you wince sometimes depending on the area they are sampling. But it is nowhere near as bad in my opinion as you are imagining. I had a lymph node biopsied one time and that was the most painful of any, yet still perfectly manageable. I would say I've had equivalent pain from dental treatment over the years. I'm sure others will chip in with their experiences for you to draw from. I hope this all turns out to be a nothingness for you, but please hang around with us until you find out and let us know. (((Hugs))))
Posts.Title: 22yo terrified of core biopsy - and, well, everything

Posts.Content: Responses thought of hours afterwards. ... I'm sorry, I actually thought you wanted to know how I was. In future I'll remember that you are merely looking for an opportunity to put me down.  I'm sorry, you seem to have left your humanity at home today, would you like some of mine?  What a nasty thing to say ( followed by intense puzzled stare ) Alternatively bring her here and we can take turns in throwing filigrastin injections at her! What a mean person....  ((((Hugs))))) to you, and feel free to milk them!!!
Posts.Title: Really bloody angry !!!

Posts.Content: Hi and welcome to the group,  It's lovely of you to be looking out for your father this way. I'm not an expert and your father's cancer is different to mine being triple negative (mine is ER positive) but, I would expect that the mass was removed, with clear margins i.e. The whole cancer was taken away with a border of good cells. He would have either had lymph nodes from the armpit removed, or the surgeon didn't think it appropriate. Then the chemo and radio kill off any stray cells which may be lurking. i don't know what happens at his next appointment, as I haven't got that far myself. It all sounds as if his treatment is almost over and he will then just be monitored periodically. I'm sure someone else who knows a little more will be able to help  Best wishes X
Posts.Title: Male Breast Cancer- chemo then what?!

Posts.Content: Hi, It does sound like your veins have become damaged. I had this after my second chemo and did think it was down to the skill of the nurse who had wrestled the cannula in. Perhaps it would have happened anyway, who knows. I was given hirudoid cream but I don't feel it did much to ease the pain. I still have this discomfort now as the veins slowly repair after chemo. The heartburn is an easier fix! If you mention it at your onco appointment they can prescribe a daily tablet, mine was lansoprazole and removed all traces of discomfort. Best wishes for the rest of your chemo X
Posts.Title: Pain in wrist and arm and restricted movement from elbow after chemo...

Posts.Content: Hi All, I've just sat down with a G&T to watch TV and suddenly my left nostril and my upper lip have gone noticibly numb. My upper lip has been twitching all day. I've googled and have seen a term called peripheral neuropathy which seems to fit the bill and sounds familiar from either these boards, or from something I've read. I'm halfway through FEC-T, having had my last FEC a fortnight ago. Anyone have any ideas?
Posts.Title: Numb nostril

Posts.Content: Thanks, it was strange and worrying, but now gone almost back to normal so I'll give them a call in the morning. Was having such a good day too!
Posts.Title: Numb nostril

Posts.Content: Hi All I have had a mastectomy with temporary implant and am currently 'odd' until I have my permanent reconstruction.  I contacted my breast care nurse who put me in touch with a prosthetics advisor who then gave me a jelly like prosthetic to even me up a little. It works well and gives me confidence to wear close fitting things. Best wishes
Posts.Title: Reconstruction and natural boob bra query

Posts.Content: Hi The shooting pains I am familiar with. I believe it is a result of the nerves knitting back together. Mine would make me throw my arms up in shock! I'm sure others will be along to confirm, though if you are at all worried please contact your breast care nurse. Best wishes Xxxx
Posts.Title: Advice re breast pain

Posts.Content: Hi all, many thanks for your responses. Very often the answer is ‘contact the Breast care nurse’ and this is probably where the problem lies. I don’t like, or trust mine. I’ll have to call though. I never seem to get sorted until she is off and someone else is filling in! as for menopause... who knows.  My last period was the same day as my first Chemo and it only lasted the one day and haven’t had one since.  Cheers everyone x
Posts.Title: Two years since Chemo what now

Posts.Content: Hi all, not been here in a while.  Diagnosed November 2016. Lumpectomy December 2016 followed by mastectomy in January 2017. Chemo February to June 2017, radiotherapy July 2017. Permanent reconstruction in November 2018.  I’m on tamoxifen. Also amitriptyline for what I think is peripheral neuropathy but not formally diagnosed. I take magnesium supplements to counteract really bad pain in my hands and trigger thumb which almost stopped me in my tracks. Presumably caused by the tamoxifen but with so many chemical changes in such a short space of time, who can possibly say?! I’m curious about when I should see an oncologist again? I haven’t seen mine since June 2017. Is this usual? Another question I have, I have pain in my collarbone and sometimes up my neck. I’ve mentioned it to my GP who sent me for a chest X-ray even though I knew and she confirmed that it would only show up something quite far advanced and not anything in early stages. Anyone else have anything like this? I don’t mind bad or good stories. thanks in advance
Posts.Title: Two years since Chemo what now

Posts.Content: Hi I had a nipple sparing mastectomy in January and although I am only a short way through the process (haven't had my permanent reconstruction yet) I have no sensation in my nipple. Hope this helps
Posts.Title: Double masectomy or masectomy and lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi I didn't have the oncotype test. I was told pretty much from the start that I would have chemo. My breast surgeon, my breast nurse, then my oncologist told me this. But when it came down to it, the oncologist told me that statistically the chemo would only give me an improvement of 4% which astounded me at the time. I'm half way through chemo as we speak and I haven't regretted grabbing every chance of improvement I can get. My point is, even if your medical team insist on chemo, the improvement is small, yet they recommend it.  There are people who say no to chemo. I just wanted every chance of cleansing myself of cancer.  Others will be along with more advice or experience. Good luck with your decisions, very difficult Xxx
Posts.Title: Help Oncotype result!! Advice please x

Posts.Content: Welcome Frances The ladies here will take good care of you and help you through if you need it. Good luck with your diagnosis as it could be something other than cancer.  Keep your chin up ((hugs)) X
Posts.Title: Waiting for a diagnosis

Posts.Content: Hi Banjoman Welcome to the group. So nice to see you here looking out for your wife. I had what my GP described as 'tethering' on the outer part of my breast which did indicate breast cancer in my case. As others have said, this does not mean that your wife's diagnosis will be cancer, but it's wise to consider all eventualities.  You mentioned that the biopsy was causing dread. (I don't actually know the definition of a core biopsy) The small biopsies taken at the time of ultrasound are only mildly painful, local anaesthetic is used to numb the entry area making them altogether manageable. I wish you both the best  Xxx
Posts.Title: Indentation

Posts.Content: HiBanjoman, My cancer is now removed by means of a mastectomy. I am halfway through my chemotherapy regime, with radiotherapy and long term medication to follow. I am of a positive mindset and looking forward to getting back to normal, perhaps starting in July or August by returning to work.  As everyone here will tell you, one day at a time is the only way to progress through this journey.  Best wishes, and keep us updated! X
Posts.Title: Indentation

Posts.Content: Hi Cartwheels I didn't cold cap and began to lose my hair day fifteen after first FEC. That was a Thursday and by Tuesday it was almost all gone. If it is going to fall out it will be quite sore first like you've had a pony tail in too tight, that sort of pain. Good luck x
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Hi all Had my third FEC today.  I was given anti sickness by tablet instead of intravenously. I have had issues with painful veins after my last treatment so not sure if it was done for this reason? Has anyone else been switched like this? I was fine energy and sickness wise last time but this time I'm wiped out and feel just a bit gippy.
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Hi All Had the first of my T (from that famous duo FEC-T) yesterday. I was worried sick about changing to a different drug as I had the FEC and all of its side effects covered! Up to now, hot flushes and that's it! I know that many effects kick in at day 2 or 3 but I'm just really glad as I go to a Macmillan craft session on a Friday and it looks like I may still be able to attend today. I thought I'd be incapacitated. Also I discussed with my nurse consultant how I felt about filigrastin injections. For some reason I have not enjoyed one bit either the daily injection or the side effects (most worrying, intense anger!)? My partner hasn't really relished administering these but has always said,"no it's fine". The nurse consultant has prescribed me a slow release one off injection taken 24 hours after chemo, which may still have the side effects but will rid me of the daily dread for both me and my partner. Please let me stay problem free until I get home at 2.30 today! Let's get crafting!
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Hi All I'm on day three after my first T docetaxol. I managed to get done the things I wanted to (grocery shopping and Macmillan craft on Friday, dropping my daughter off at her friends house yesterday) but have now crashed. Feel like an old man, aches in hips and legs, headache. Feet tingly and tired. Yesterday I had toothache the like of which I haven't had since eating tons of candy floss as a kid, just a general every tooth aching slightly. Today my tongue feels burnt and sore and is forcing itself into the centre of my thoughts. Taste also seems to be leaving me, I had my favourite strawberries, blueberries, crushed choc digestive and strawberry yoghurt dessert yesterday and could hardly taste it.  Is this stinging, sore tongue thing something I can expect to last? Or have I had one choc digestive too many! Oh and happy bank holiday weekend, our weather here has picked up a tiny bit to make me feel a little more human....
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Hi Jenny I am halfway through my chemo, and have spent only one day in bed. I'd overdone it for the two days previous. And even then I got up and made my meals and went back to bed.  I get up every day at 7 to get my daughter up for school. I often have a quick lie down while watching tv but suffer very little true exhaustion. As always, everyone is different. Hope this helps x
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Four days after my first 'T' I feel like I've met my match! Not sure if it's the T or the peg injection but everything hurts. Walking, eating, drinking, laying dow, sitting up.  Can anyone advise if they have had nails aching, but haven't had them fall off? My nails feel really sore. I feel like I'm in that nightmare where all your teeth fall out, except it's nails, and it's real! Thanks
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Off to my bloods and oncology appointment in the morning and then third FEC on Thursday. I don't want to go! I'm so so sick of needles and veins and cannulas and filigrastin and steroids and mouthwash! Miserable as sin, and drinking gin! I have one bad week, one good week and then one week crying / dreading the next lot / being a misery! Roll on the good week! I'm bloody annoyed!
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Hi All I'm third FEC on Thursday coming. That's the halfway mark in sight. Slightly concerned about my first 'T' as it feels a little like the unknown. Once that first one is done I'm then two thirds of the way through and closer to that holiday I've promised myself when this is all over! Roll on June!
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Thanks for the info guys, I feel like I've been let off lightly so I'll relish the day! I have a very red face and hot flushes but still very mobile and pain free! Yippee! (Not thinking any further than today....)
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Cartwheels Happy bank holiday weekend ladies! Although, being off work and having chemo brain I sometimes have no idea what day of the week it is.... Just wanted to share a weird side effect that I've not heard mentioned elsewhere. I've noticed that my wee smells quite pungent since starting chemo (a bit like the way asparagus gives you smelly wee). I guess it's all the drugs working their way through, but quite amused me! x Hi Cartwheels  Agree on the wee thing, even though I've drunk enough water to fill an ocean! Also 'what day is it again? ' that's me!
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: I agree with mistymoley, request an urgent appointment. When I called the doctors I specifically said ' I need an appointment asap because I have had some changes in my breast which are causing me concern'. I didn't want the receptionist to try to put me off in any way. I also agree, calmly request a referral. If one isn't made, then immediately make another appointment with another doctor.  Good luck xxxx
Posts.Title: How to get taken seriously by GP

Posts.Content: Hi Chelseabun, I have had mastectomy with temporary expander implant in January. I think my experience won't really fit with what you'll be having done apart from the expander bit. I had a right side skin saving, nipple sparing mastectomy and then an expander fitted, with veritas (bovine tissue sling)  which I believe is attached to my pectoral laid over the top of the expander.  I had an absolutely awful time trying to decide which way to go with reconstruction, or to even go the other way and go flat both sides! The reason for expander rather than immediate implant was the fact I would be having radiotherapy as a definite and I didn't want to have good work done to potentially fail.  My sister had a mastectomy saving no skin recently, just a month or so before me,  and she had the expander to stretch her skin to allow an implant to be fitted. Hers is going along perfectly and she is due replacements in a month or two. She is in Spain. I'm not sure what has happened in my case. I am half way through chemo and will then move on to radiotherapy. My expander has never really looked right. In the back of my mind I think i have too much skin for it to sit behind but that could just be my imagination ( I can make things fit so well since having cancer!) My oncologist thinks the expander has been pierced when having a seroma drained but I'm not convinced. It is as if the expander has rolled over and fallen to the bottom.... One of my two surgeons called in sick of the morning of my surgery, I was in tears. I don't want to think that had anything to do with it Given all of that bad news!!! The veritas  has performed perfectly. I have a small strange boob currently, and can see and feel some of the outline of the edges of the expander and I have a pointed bit which uncomfortably sticks up next to my nipple. I didn't actually expect anything better, and have accepted the faults as this was an entirely temporary situation. The veritas does cause a reaction with the body but in a very mild, polite way with a little discolouration initially. The pectoral part doesn't complain at all, and it's just the expander that gives me a little discomfort. If I overdo things lifting or activity wise, it can be more uncomfortable and the seroma I've been fending off comes back a little to put me in my place.  I must be honest and say I'd love to be done with the discomfort, treatment, surgery, chemicals etc but I feel extremely lucky that after all of this, I will have a breast, and I will be alive! As for recovery, I'm not sure what to say... I have chemo and radio to do. My scar is totally healed and if not for the other treatments, I'm ready now for a permanent implant! I can lift, I can function, I can drive,  I sometimes need rest and can't do lots of things, for lots of days in a row, but I'm quite physically active at home as nobody seems to be able to do anything 'like Mam does it...!' Which goes from ironing, to dishes, to gardening, to playing ball with the dog and beyond! I hope my experience hasn't put you off, as I'm fairly happy with where I'm at. Many good wishes for your future choices and procedures,  Xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Reconstruction with expanders

Posts.Content: Hi Chelseabun I can imagine that when you can see the finish line it could be very tempting to just throw off your caution and run like hell for the end! I can't really see mine yet so I can only imagine!  The way I see the two stage recon is that all of the big stuff is got out of the way first. The removal of breast tissue is both physically and mentally challenging. Once that is done, the second stage should , in theory, be just a tidy up job. If you need any revision etc, they can correct bits and pieces when they go in for the second time. The second op will require far less invasion, and the recovery time should be much much shorter.  Good luck, you're almost there!
Posts.Title: Reconstruction with expanders

Posts.Content: Hi All I've just read Kacang on another thread. (Sorry I don't know how to tag ) Quote: "Also, I really didn't think I felt ill when I was diagnosed. However, now that I've been out the other side for several months, I realise that I wasn't really well for quite some time before diagnosis. Tired, listless, slightly breathless, lacking the mental energy to engage with anything. I'd put all the symptoms down to "getting old"; now I know there's no such thing and I feel at least 10 years younger."  What she just said rings quite true with me. I was always getting told 'you're turning old before your time' etc and didn't have any energy for anything. I used to be constantly planning little trips, days out, taking it on myself to rearrange furniture, decorate, clean. Worked overtime, couldn't stop! And then the last few years I've just done the bare minimum. I have wondered if this was the cancer getting a grip on me but my partner dismissed it, and I thought perhaps I was just imagining it (I think having cancer enhances your imagination skills!) but it worried me and I was thinking that I've got a long time left to be feeling this old.  I wonder if there's something in it, and if I will feel as Kacang does when I get through this? Is this a 'thing'? Does anyone else feel similar? Food for thought indeed!
Posts.Title: Feeling old and tired before diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Hi all I still use a mans disposable razor. I also have NEVER cut myself shaving under my arms and am willing to take the risk. I am extremely careful as my armpit is completely numb after surgery for sentinel node removal and then full axillary clearance. As luck would have it, my chemo has taken the underarm hair away. Sadly, not the leg hair! X
Posts.Title: Under arm hair.......
